content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash! Enjoyed it! I think the reverse is such a cool idea!

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good contribution, not too difficult, not too easy
Nice clash! Is there any particular reason for rounding the result up?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The "reverse" value makes this problem much trickier and relatively unique compared to other equation-based evaluation clashes. It may also catch clashers using languages with "eval" functions (e.g. Python, JavaScript) off-guard by forcing character replacement.

In validator 6, is there intended to be a space between the first hyphen and the digit one? Also, I wonder if the statement or constraints should possibly mention whether division by zero should be considered, and if so, what should be outputted (‚àû, NaN, Undefined, etc).

Similar clashes exist:

- https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/776443c1f96f0a4d2fcd9bc82bd770628c51
- https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/576775cc83346ab14f5c99e5d53a97fc45cc
- https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/11533e190b55b63be956c0a928a28afdbe6fe
Is it really a problem or can I still try posting it ? Moreover the second one you mentioned doesn‚Äôt seem to be really the same.
Thanks for your comment. I addressed the issues tell me if you like it better now =)

My sample shortest code (163 chars) using eval, for my reference:

import math
i=input
r=i()!='no'
f=lambda x,y:x.replace(y[0],y[~r])
s=f(f(f(f(f(i(),'/*/'),'x/*'),'-~-'),'+-+'),'~+-')
print('Error'if '/ 0'in s else math.ceil(eval(s)))
No, it was just to make the clash a bit trickier =)
Thank you very much for the approving !!

Hello,

Thank you for your message ! It‚Äôs my first contribution so I‚Äôm really happy to see that some people are enjoying it.

Again, thank you for approving =)
Hey! Its my pleasure! Your idea is really cool. Wish you all the best :)
Fair enough :-)
Thank you for approving my problem! And also thank you for all the advice and the final code you provided! I hope you found it entertaining üëç

It looks good. I like the "reverse" twist. The note "( there will be no division by 0 in s if you need to reverse it )" in the statement could maybe be more clear as test 7 does output "Error" while needing to be reversed. Also, just nitpicking but there is a small typo in paragraph 2 of your statement (wich instead of which).
Hey, thanks again for reviewing my work! I‚Äôve fixed the points you mentioned ‚Äî let me know if you think it‚Äôs good now.
looks good!

Yeah the second one doesn't seem to be the same.

I would encourage you to put your own unique twist on this clash before publishing :) The first clash in particular is somewhat interesting because it removes the multiplication-division precedence over addition and subtraction (although I would argue that it's not really that suitable as a Reverse clash).
Okay thanks for the advice I will work on it !

I agree with @User123's suggestion that you add your own twist before publishing your contribution. In addition to being similar to existing clashes, your clash also unfairly favours programming languages with an `eval` function (such as Python or JavaScript).

Putting that aside, here are my other comments on your clash:

Goal
* Please format "s" as a [[variable]].

* Please add "representing an expression" before "consisting".

* Please change "positive" to "non-negative", since 0 appears as an operand in some test cases.

* Please change "separated by" to "and".

* Please change "symbols" to "basic operators" to match the term used in the Input section.

* Please format the operators (excluding commas) as {{constants}}.

* Please move the entire sentence "Division by 0‚Ä¶" to after "these operations".

* Please change "these operations" to "the expression".

* Please add that no rounding should be performed during division and that only the final output should be rounded up.

Input
* Please rewrite for precision as follows:

<<Line 1:>> A string [[s]] representing an expression consisting of non-negative integers and basic operators separated by a space.

Output
* Please change "operations" to "expression".

Constraints
* Please change 1000 to 100.

* Please change "[[len(s)]]" to "length of [[s]]".

* Please add:
  0 ‚â§ each operand in [[s]] ‚â§ 2‚Åµ¬≥
  0 ‚â§ absolute value of output ‚â§ 2‚Åµ¬≥ (for non-error cases)

Stub generator
* Please change 1000 to 100.

* Please add a write statement, e.g. write answer.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with slightly different inputs and outputs (including operands of similar magnitude). Please revise the following pairs accordingly:

  ‚Ä¢ Test 1 and Validator 1: Add subtraction.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Validator 2: Remove addition.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Test 3: Add subtraction and division which results in a fraction.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Test 5 and Validator 5: Include a few more additions and subtractions at the end of the expression.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Test 6 and Validator 6: Ensure operands are of similar magnitude.

Thanks.
Thank you very much for your guidance, it's my first time contributing so I'm more prone making mistakes and I apologize for that. Please tell me if it's more suitable now.

No problem! We all learn from our mistakes.

Goal
* Please list all four switching rules explicitly. The statement should clearly state the complete set of rules; the players shouldn't be expected to guess the omitted rules based on the examples.

* Please remove the following sentence:

"If you need to reverse the expression, you will be given a valid input string s (no division by zero), but it may still produce an Error output."

Instead, update the phrase "reversed or not" to "reversed first if required", which captures the intended meaning, and makes the above sentence unnecessary.

Input
* Please revise the Line 2 description for precision as follows:

<<Line 2:>> A string [[s]] representing an expression consisting of non-negative integers and basic operators separated by a space.

Output
* Please change "reversed or not" to "reversed first if required".

Cases
* Please use Validator 7 as the new Test 8.

* Then create a new Validator 7 ([[reverse]] = yes) and a new Validator 8 ([[reverse = no]]), both with the expected output "Error".

Thanks.
Hey thank you again for your return, I just finished fixing the points you mentioned. Do you think it's ready to be published ?

Thanks for making the edits @Tikax :) The reverse string is indeed a unique twist.

I am personally against this being a Reverse clash (note: different from your reverse string) because players will only get to see "reverse: yes" or "reverse: no", and they may not be able to deduce that "reverse" refers to the switching of operations just by looking at the numerical output alone. But that's just my opinion.

Perhaps also include a test, e.g.: 5 x 4 / 4 x 0, that forces left-to-right evaluation of multiplication and division.
Hey, thanks for your message. I‚Äôve made the changes you mentioned, and I agree that it‚Äôs not really suitable for Reverse mode based on the current test. Let me know if everything looks good now.
Thank you for following up. For me, the only thing left is to remove the trailing newlines from the input to Validator 7.
